text: Hi guys!

I'm Laura Vitale and on this episode of Laura
in the Kitchen I want to show you how I make
my breakfast turnovers.

Now, by no means am recommending that you
eat these for breakfast every day, they are

definitely a treat, but when you do want to
splurge a little, or when you have someone

over for brunch and you want to make something
a little bit special yet so simple and easy,
these are the ones I think you will go to.
Because they really are basic.

Let's start off with some of the ingredients
we'll need.

We need some eggs, I have some breakfast sausages
here that I have removed the casing, I've

got some chopped green onions, some butter,
some salt-free steak seasoning, a little bit
of cream and some salt.

You will also need some puff pastry, but that
is going to come in a little bit.

Now these don't look like they will be much
of anything crazy and good, but believe me
when I tell you they are fantastic!

I have a large skillet here pre-heating over
about medium heat.

I am adding a little bit of butter, I am going
to melt my butter, you also want to make sure
your oven is pre-heating to 400 at this point.

You are also going to need some sharp cheddar,
that has been grated.

It's in the fridge for now because it's really
kind of hot in the kitchen and I don't want

to melt the cheese and get the puff pastry
soft, so I'm keeping that in there until we
need it.

And now, to my skillet, I'm adding in my breakfast
sausages - now you can use bacon if you want

to, you can use veggies, it's completely up
to you, I'm just using breakfast sausage,

and this is actually turkey breakfast sausage,
and I'm just breaking it up with my wooden
spoon.

And I did remove the casing, you don't have
to, but I like to, and I'm just kind of breaking

these up a little bit - or as much as I can
really with my wooden spoon.

These look good enough, I'm going to add in
my scallions and let those cook together.

Now because I used turkey, my sausage didn't
really render a lot of fat, but if your sausage

renders a lot of fat then by all means, I
would get rid of it because you don't want
that all in your dish.

Okay, to my eggs, I'm adding in my steak seasoning
which sounds crazy, I'm well aware, but trust

me when I tell you the end result will be
fantastic.
Add some salt.

Now you want to make sure when you buy seasoning,
that you buy it salt free so that you can

control the amount of salt that goes into
your dish because so often, pre-made mixes

like steak seasoning, they are so salty that
by the time you add enough to get a big bunch

of flavor, the dish is so salty that you can't
even enjoy it.

I've added my cream and I'm just whisking
my eggs and my cream together.

You can add milk if you want to, but I just
think this makes it a little bit richer - like

they really need to be any richer, but since
this is for a really special brunch or get
together, I figured I'd go all the way.

Now I'm just going to wait for my sausages
to cook all the way through which will take
about another minute or so.

And then we'll get going on adding in the
eggs.

I'm going to add in just one more tablespoon
of butter because I want my eggs to be really

buttery and delicious and cook in butter because
that's my favorite way of cooking scrambled
eggs.
Add in your eggs.

And now you are going to just cook these enough
for about two to three minutes so that they

hold their shape and you want to just stir
them the entire time.

You don't want to cook these enough that they
look dry, because remember that these are

going to go into the oven, they're going to
be protected by the puff pastry, but you don't

want to over cook them because it can be really
tough and rubbery.
It is a protein after all.

So, I'm just going to cook these for about,
literally two to three minutes or until they're

scrambled but they're still just a slight
bit runny and then we'll get going on making
our little turnovers with them.

Now you can see that my eggs still look a
little bit wet and I've just turned it off
because that's exactly where I want them.

And now I'm going to add in my extra sharp
cheddar, but I have turned the heat off, and

I'm just going to let that sit just like that,
I'm not going to stir it in or anything.

I'm just going to leave it as-is, clean up,
get my puff pastry and make our turnovers.

I took my puff pastry out of the fridge, and
I've just rolled it on a lightly floured surface

so that it was about an inch bigger on all
four sides.

Now I'm going to take my knife and I'm going
to cut this into four.

Just like so, and then we're going to take
a spoonful of our mixture, put it a little
bit closer to me.

I like to do this like an assembly line because
I just think it makes it a lot easier to do
- this side.

Brush all four sides with some egg wash which
is just one egg beaten with a little bit of
milk or cream or water or anything like that.

And then all you are going to do is - we are
going to do like we do our strawberry turnovers

or any other turnovers that we've made here
we are going to fold these over like so, stretch

them a bit if you need to, it's perfectly
fine, and then seal.
Put them on there.
We are going to seal them with a fork.

Dip it into some flour and seal the edges
shut.

Just going to make a little slit on each one
so that the steam can escape.

I should probably have used a paring knife,
but you know what, living on the edge.

And then I am going to brush these with some
of the egg wash and I am going to pop these

into the oven and let them bake for about
20 minutes or until they are beautiful, lightly
golden brown and puffed up and just gorgeous.

I"m going to pop these in, work on the second
tray, get those in the oven and I'll show

you what they look like once they all are
done and cooled a bit so we can dig right
in.

My turnovers were in the oven for around 22
minutes or so I have let them cool for about

maybe 10 minutes because they were really
hot when they came out.
Ahh.

They are so flaky and they smell so incredibly
good.
Mmm.
Heaven in a bite!
Look at that!
The eggs are not dry at all, at all, at all!
The pastry is really flaky.

Now this is undeniably a treat, not something
I eat everyday for breakfast or even on a

weekly basis, but it definitely a great recipe
to have in your back pocket.

If you want to make something kind of cool
yet different and impressive for someone for
brunch, these are the ones to make.

LauraintheKitchen.com will have you covered
with the recipe, I hope you have enjoyed spending

time with me, let me know if you have a personal
recipe for breakfast turnovers and how you

like them because I would love to try different
variations, and maybe show them here on Laura
in the Kitchen!

Hope you have enjoyed spending time with me
and I'll see you next time!
Bye bye.
